number of helpful: 59 of 62 people (95%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Being both a ship fan (both naval AND sci-fi) and a steampunk fan, I smiled at the idea of this game and quickly slapped it onto my wish list, which then my friend got for me for Christmas.  I really should have looked at the reviews first.Graphics:The ship models themselves look nice, but that's it.  The skies all look bland and the water has no real detail except for the reflection of the ships and sky.  The damage the ships take only amounts to brun marks, tattered flags (the flags that ALL point in the same direction ALL the time) and fire.  There are no break models, so when a ship is destroyed, it just sinks.  Also, there are NO graphic options.  No resolution choice, no graphics scailer, nothing.Sound:The sound seems fine except, for me, it is tied to where the camera is in relation to the ship, and if you're off center, the sound ALL comes from one speaker.  The music quickly gets boring.  Also, THERE IS NO VOLUME CONTROL TO SPEAK OF!  The sound literally jars you unless you turn your computer's sound down!Controls:You don't get to actually DO anything except control the game speed (slow, less slow), ship speed and ship direction.  And it takes several seconds for the game to repsond to those commands.  I am not sure if this was an oversight or intended for more realism, but it does this game NO favors.  Also, having NO control over your weapons ensures that you will just sit there, occasionally toggling controls and waiting for something to happen.Gameplay:WHAT GAMEPLAY!?  All you do is pick a battle, pick a side, see a little paragraph about it, and then you are thrown into the battle.  NO ship or fleet customization, no weapon setups, nothing.  You get what you get and hope that you move just right for ships to think about firing.  And then you play the waiting game until soemthing happens.  Most of the time, it's either your ships or the enemy ships running away.  I have no clue what triggers this, but it happens often.  You lose control of that ship and watch it run off to do God knows what, leaving you do fend for yourself.  One by one, your ships flee.  I would guess it is because of damage, but since there is no way to fix damage or anything, it's just a matter of praying that more of their ships flee than yours; and also praying that they don't decide to stay around and keep shooting, which they are prone to do.  Your ships MAY also come running back, but will more often than not, just sit sail by and give your the middle finger.  Most battles take the ENTIRE hour and a half time limit (if not most of it) and after it's over, you feel like you just sat there, screaming at a movie and not a game.All in all, avoid this game and ALL of Toten Game's lineup (reviews on this games mirror the sentiment of this review).  There are battle naval combat games available on Steam.

												Not even worth the reduced prices. I was excited when I saw the screen shots of the ship models... but that turned out to be the only positive about the game. The controls are EXTREMELY limited and there is no setting area to change them. Also, you can only choose to fight 6 or so battles. content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												No customization - including graphics - no tutorial, and not even a hint of a campaign to guide you through how to play means you're on your own when you start. So, I picked a battle, and had no idea what I was supposed to do. I turns out that your only options are telling the ship formations (not even individual ships) to speed up, slow down, go left, or go right. Then, you sit back and watch them beat the crap out of each other. That's it. I walked away from the computer during a battle for 15 minutes and came back because there was nothing for me to do. It is a fascinating time period, and I'm going to force myself to play the scenarios so I can get some hint of my money's worth. If you're a fan of that period, then $3 might be worth the price, but not more than that.

												Absolute garbage of a game.There is no options menu, there is barely any user interface, the graphics look horrendus, and there is no strategy.  All you can control is the movement of ships.  Nothing else.  You control the lead ship in a column of other ships, and you try and maneuver your line of ships into an advantageous point.That's it.Ships fire independently of eachother.  You cannot order them to focus fire on one specific ship.  You cannot make your columns of ships break and move independently.  There is no easy way to keep track of the entire battle.Don't buy this.  Full stop.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												I really enjoy historical naval combat games and that was the reason I have titles such as Empire, Napoleon and Shogun 2 Total War Fall of the Samurai. Then, I had been researching about 19th century naval warfare but unfortunately there are not trully interest aside Totem Games and Fall of the Samurai DLC to make games set in this fascinating era. Victorian Admirals is focused on 4 historical scenarios set in 1880s: Caroline Island Crisis 1885; Panama Crisis 1885; Marianas Incident 1887; Samoan Crisis 1889. The ships of the period are transitional between sailing ships and pre-dreadnought with steam powered engines. There is a great variety of ship models including gunboats, light and heavy frigates and monitors. The ship models are trully detailed, especially the damage textures, and the environment graphics look good as well with beautiful colors set in the Pacific and Caribbean. I also enjoy the engine and cannon sounds.For those who complain about the lack of customization, the game is indeed customizable. Just go to Victorian Admirals and you will find a file Config where you can customize video settings and sounds settings, including music if you don't want to hear music while playing or to lower the volume of the music. I have this game maxed out and the graphics improve substantially, take a look at my video on youtube:


YouTube™ Video: Victorian Admirals Caroline Islands Crisis 1885 Spain 

			Views: 174		

			Victorian Admirals Caroline Islands Crisis 1885 Spain		

I am glad Totem Games has another games covering other conflicts of this era: American Civil War, Chincha Islands War, Anglo-Russian War among others. The next title of Ironclads II War of the Pacific will cover another new and exciting conflict between Peru and Chile. I Can't wait for the release!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Another very poor offering from Totem Games latest in their "Ironclads" series.  The name may have changed but the game has barely evolved from 2010's Ironclads High Seas.  Even the in-game music sounds strangely familiar...In this game you have a selection of about five different scenarios.  Each battle is a simple open-sea fleet action - no islands or other terrain.  The in-battle UI has changed a little, but the gameplay remains fundamentally the same - you can direct the speed and course of each squadron of ships and choose whether ships can fire at will or hold their fire.  And that's it.  You can't control individual ships, you just steer the leader and the other ships blindly follow.  If the second or third ship in a squadron is at risk of colliding with another ship, there is absolutely nothing you can do to avoid it.  You can't target ships guns, or choose different ammunition types, and there's no firefighting or damage control functions.To put things in perspective, I'm a tabletop wargamer and history buff.  I love the Ironclad naval era.  I was absolutely bored to tears by this game, and resent having paid full price for it.  Even if it's on sale, don't bother.  However cheap it is, you won't get your money's worth.
